If you remain dissatisfied with the response provided then you can contact the PCC by clicking here.
Doncaster Free Press provides news, events and sport features from the Doncaster area. For the best up to date information relating to Doncaster and the surrounding areas visit us at Doncaster Free Press regularly or bookmark this page.
For you to enjoy all the features of this website Doncaster Free Press requires permission to use cookies.
Allow Cookies
Find Out More â¼
What is a Cookie?
What is a Flash Cookie?
Can I opt out of receiving Cookies?
About our Cookies
Cookies are small data files which are sent to your browser (Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome etc) from a website you visit. They are stored on your electronic device.
This is a type of cookie which is collected by Adobe Flash media player (it is also called a Local Shared Object) - a piece of software you may already have on your electronic device to help you watch online videos and listen to podcasts.
Yes there are a number of options available, you can set your browser either to reject all cookies, to allow only "trusted" sites to set them, or to only accept them from the site you are currently on.
However, please note - if you block/delete all cookies, some features of our websites, such as remembering your login details, or the site branding for your local newspaper may not function as a result.
The types of cookies we, our ad network and technology partners use are listed below:
Revenue Science âº
A tool used by some of our advertisers to target adverts to you based on pages you have visited in the past. To opt out of this type of targeting you can visit the 'Your Online Choices' website by clicking here.
Google Ads âº
Our sites contain advertising from Google; these use cookies to ensure you get adverts relevant to you. You can tailor the type of ads you receive by visiting here or to opt out of this type of targeting you can visit the 'Your Online Choices' website by clicking here.
Webtrends / Google Analytics âº
This is used to help us identify unique visitors to our websites. This data is anonymous and we cannot use this to uniquely identify individuals and their usage of the sites.
Dart for Publishers âº
This comes from our ad serving technology and is used to track how many times you have seen a particular ad on our sites, so that you don't just see one advert but an even spread. This information is not used by us for any other type of audience recording or monitoring.
ComScore âº
ComScore monitor and externally verify our site traffic data for use within the advertising industry. Any data collected is anonymous statistical data and cannot be traced back to an individual.
Local Targeting âº
Our Classified websites (Photos, Motors, Jobs and Property Today) use cookies to ensure you get the correct local newspaper branding and content when you visit them. These cookies store no personally identifiable information.
Grapeshot âº
We use Grapeshot as a contextual targeting technology, allowing us to create custom groups of stories outside out of our usual site navigation. Grapeshot stores the categories of story you have been exposed to. Their privacy policy and opt out option can be accessed here.
Subscriptions Online âº
Our partner for Newspaper subscriptions online stores data from the forms you complete in these to increase the usability of the site and enhance user experience.
Add This âº
Add This provides the social networking widget found in many of our pages. This widget gives you the tools to bookmark our websites, blog, share, tweet and email our content to a friend.
3rd Party Cookies âº
We use Advertising agencies to provide us with some of the advertising on our websites. These include (but are not limited to) Specific Media, The Rubicon Project, AdJug, AdConion, Context Web. Please click on the provider name to visit their opt-out page.
docs.title: Doncaster Free Press

content_text: Metro Â» Richard Hookham | Metro UK Metro Â» Richard Hookham | Metro UK Metro.co.uk: News, Sport, Showbiz, Celebrities from Metro Newspaper Whereâs yer tool? Six ways Jose Mourinhoâs Chelsea can break down stubborn defensive walls Six tools - not necessarily Black and Decker - Jose Mourinho could use to break down stubborn defensive walls. Andy Murray says on Twitter he is getting married â but then quickly backtracks Andy Murray has told the world he is to tie the knot this summer after answering a fan's question on Twitter. Yevhen Konoplyankaâs dad confirms English interest as Liverpool prepare to swoop Yevhen Konoplyanka's dad has confirmed the Dnipro and Ukraine forward is poised to move to England, as Liverpool officials to try and cut a deal. Manchester United given lift by new-boy Juan Mata and Robin van Persie Record-signing Juan Mata made an impressive debut as Manchester United breathed new life into their faltering season with a crucial 2-0 victory over Cardiff. 2014 Formula One cars could be more dangerous, warns Red Bull chief Adrian Newey Red Bull technical chief Adrian Newey has warned F1's newest cars have become more dangerous. Kelvin Davis says troublemakers arenât welcome at Southampton after Dani Osvaldo ban Skipper Kelvin Davis insists troublemakers won’t be allowed to wreck team morale at Southampton in the wake of the Dani Osvaldo bust-up. Striker Osvaldo was handed a two-week ban by the club last week after a training-ground bust-up in which he was accused of head-butting team-mate Jose Fonte. It is believed the Italian could now […] Alastair Cookâs tour by numbers as England lose final ODI to Australia Alastair Cook ends his miserable tour to Australia ended with a five-run defeat in the fifth ODI in Adelaide to ensure a humbling 4-1 series defeat. Englandâs Ashes flops told by village club: Weâll let you win for Â£100 A village club is offering Alastair Cook's England a Â£100 deal to thrash them to boost their shattered confidence. And they'll throw in a free 'tea!' Australian Open 2014: Eugenie Bouchard cuddles up with more furry friends in Melbourne Canada's Australian Open semi-finalist Eugenie Bouchard cuddles up with some furry friends in Melbourne. Australian Open 2014: Roger Federer hails battling quarter-final win over Andy Murray Roger Federer hails his battling victory over Andy Murray to reach the Australian Open semi-finals. Paul Inceâs Blackpool sacking celebrated on Instagram by former defender Ian Evatt Paul Ince's sacking by Blackpool has been joyously hailed by the club's former defender Ian Evatt. Swansea manager Michael Laudrup in danger of axe as slide continues Swansea boss Michael Laudraup's future is in serious doubt with reports claiming the club's board have met to discuss their recent slump in form. Etienne Capoueâs agent slams Tottenham for âabsurdâ Â£9m price tag which could wreck Napoli move Etienne Capoue's agent has slammed Tottenham for an 'absurd' price tag which could see him miss out on a move to Napoli. Australian Open 2014: Andy Murray v Roger Federer â Quarter-final head-to-head Andy Murray and Roger Federer will contest their 21st career meeting when they clash in the quarter-finals of the Australian Open tomorrow morning. Brass band could wind up Vladimir Putin by playing gay anthem âY.M.C.A.â in Sochi A brass band could be ready to upset Russian president Vladimir Putin by playing the gay anthem 'Y.M.C.A' at the Olympic speed skating at Sochi. Tottenham target Dimitar Berbatov in cut-price Â£1.5m move from Fulham Chairman Daniel Levy could be poised for an audacious bid to bring Dimitar Berbatov back to Tottenham in a cut-price Â£1.5million deal. Alastair Cook should quit as England captain, according to Metro poll Alastair Cook should step down as captain as both the England Test and one-day side, according to a Metro online poll Quadruple hunt: Manchester City bid to succeed where Arsenal, Chelsea and Manchester United all failed Manchester City are still on course for an unprecedented quadruple - but how have their fellow big guns fared when chasing four pots in recent years? Southampton crisis: Five players up for grabs if boss Mauricio Pochettino quits Five Southampton players who could be targets if boss Mauricio Pochettino leaves in the wake of executive chairman Nicola Cortese's resignation Carlton Cole signs new 18-month West Ham deal worth Â£40,000-a-week Carlton Cole has signed a new 18-month contract with West Ham, the club has confirmed. The 30-year-old striker has been handed a deal, thought to be worth around Â£40,000 a week, after impressing since penning a short-term contract in October. The former England international was released by the Hammers last summer but has netted four […] West Ham lodge complaint to Premier League over Fulhamâs pursuit of Ravel Morrison West Ham United are to launch a complaint to the Premier League over Fulham's pursuit of Ravel Morrison. Ravel Morrison transfer bid was rejected by West Ham, reveals Rene Meulensteen Fulham have had a bid knocked back for West ham midfielder Ravel Morrison, Cottagers coach Rene Meulensteen has confirmed. Australian Open 2014: Ross Hutchins wins first match since battling back from his fight against cancer Britain's Ross Hutchins made another huge step in his remarkable fightback from cancer when he and partner Colin Fleming advanced to the second round of the men's doubles at the Australian Open. Australian Open 2014: When will it become too hot for play in Melbourne? With temperatures boiling over in Melbourne, when will it be too hot for play at the Australian Open? Jenson Buttonâs father, John, dies of a suspected heart attack Formula One driver Jenson Button's father has died of a suspected heart attack at the age of 70.
docs.title: Metro » Richard Hookham | Metro UK

What's On in Chester, Flintshire and Cheshire - February 6 onwards
Feb 06, 2014 07:50
By Michael Green
0 Comments
Share
Share
Tweet
+1
Email
Events, music, shows and exhibitions taking place throughout the area
Dirty Dancing will be screened at Ye Olde Custom House in Chester
EVENTS
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 6
CHESTER: Chester Food and Nutrition Fair - a health promotion event featuring stalls on food, nutrition and health run by third year University of Chester students of human nutrition and dietetics in the small hall on the Chester main campus off Parkgate Road. Admission free. Call 01244 513090.
CHESTER: Chester Society of Natural Science Literature and Art meeting with talk by Glyn Parry on familiar places around the Spanish coast at a time when the holidaymakers have gone home, to see what the coasts are like âoff season, at the Grosvenor Museum Lecture Theatre at 7.30pm. Call 01244 336108.
CHESTER: Chester Theatre Club holding open auditions for The Lark by Jean Anouilh, the clubâs May production, at the Little Theatre in Gloucester Street, Newtown, at 7.30pm. More details at www.chestertheatreclub.co.uk.
MOLD: Screening of the documentary Love Marilyn (12A) in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 7
MOLD: National Theatre Live Encore presents Coriolanus starring Tom Hiddleston and Mark Gatiss, in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 4pm. Tickets Â£15, concessions Â£13. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: Screening of the true life drama The Railway Man (15) starring Colin Firth in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8
CHESTER: Chester Film Society social event at St Maryâs Centre at 7.15pm. Contact 01244 371750 or 398707 or visit www.chesterfilmfans.co.uk for details.
MOLD: Screening of the true life drama The Railway Man (15) starring Colin Firth in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 11am. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: Met Opera Live presents Rusalka by Dvorak starring Renee Fleming, in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 5.55pm. Tickets Â£15, concessions Â£13. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9
CHESTER: Cheshire Phoenix v Sheffiled Sharks basketball match at Northgate Arena at 5.30pm. Adults Â£13, under 16s Â£8, family Â£30. Call 01244 380444.
KNUTSFORD: Going Digital - join expert tutor Graham Nobles of Living Image Photography who will show you how to get the best from your camera at Tatton Park. Tickets from Â£75. Call 01625 3744298 or visit www.tattonpark.org.uk.
Â 
MONDAY, FEBRUARY 10
MOLD: Screening of the true life drama The Railway Man (15) starring Colin Firth in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 11
CHESTER: Chester Photographic Society meeting with talk on Where The Wild Birds Draw Me by John Power at the Grosvenor Museum at 7.30pm. Call 01244 300166 or visit www.chesterphotographicsociety.org.uk.
ELLESMERE PORT: Chester and Merseyside IWA monthly meeting at the The Tom Rolt Conference Centre, The National Waterways Museum, at 7.45pm. The meeting will feature an illustrated talk on Historic Canalside Industry in and around Chester by Ray Buss of Chester Canal Heritage Trust. Call 0151 678 9300 for details.
MOLD: Screening of the true life drama The Railway Man (15) starring Colin Firth in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 2pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: Screening of the US drama All Is Lost (12A) starring Robert Redford in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12
CHESTER: Film night with screening of Little Miss Sunshine at Alexanderâs, Rufus Court. Admission Â£4. Doors 7.30pm. Call 01244 340005 or visit www.alexanderslive.com.
CHESTER: Chester Archaeological Society meeting with talk on Excavations in Roman Middlewich at the Grosvenor Museum at 7.30pm. Call 01244 310563 or visit www.chesterarchaeolsoc.org.uk.
MOLD: Screening of the true life drama The Railway Man (15) starring Colin Firth in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 2pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: Screening of the US drama All Is Lost (12A) starring Robert Redford in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 13
CHESTER: Chester Antiques Show - 45-50 stands of antiques and art extending over three floors at County Grandstand, Chester Racecourse from 10.30am-5.30pm. Tickets Â£5. Call 07774 850044 or visit www.penman-fairs.co.uk.
CHESTER: Talk on Just a Family Squabble? Crowned Heads of Europe 1914 by Lisa Peters at the Cheshire Military Museum at 2pm. Call 01244 327617 for details.
CHESTER: Screening of the 80s classic movie Dirty Dancing at Ye Olde Custom House on Watergate Street, from 7pm with the screening at 7.30pm. Call 01244 638936 or email karl_cleveley@yahoo.co.uk.
CHESTER: Chester FC v Halifax at the Swansway Stadium in Bumperâs Lane. Kick-off 7.30pm. Call 01244 371376.
CHESTER: Chester Society of Natural Science Literature and Art meeting with talk by Roger Croston on revisiting China, illustrating the dramatic changes which have taken place, at the Grosvenor Museum Lecture Theatre at 7.30pm. Call 01244 336108.
MOLD: Screening of the classic 1999 Oscar winner American Beauty (18) starring Kevin Spacey and directed by Sam Mendes in the Film Theatre at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£6, concessions Â£5.50. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
WARRINGTON: Warrington Wolves v Salford Red Devils at the Halliwell Jones Stadium in Mike Gregory Way at 8pm. Adults from Â£19.50, concessions from Â£13.50. Call 01925 248880.
MUSIC
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 6
CHESTER: Philip Rushforth presents a lunchtime organ recital in Chester Cathedral at 1.10pm. Admission Â£5.45, concessions Â£4.50. Accompanied children under 16 free
Â 
SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 8
CHESTER:Â  Chester Cathedral Nave Choir presents Lux Aeterna: Music for Candlemas at 7.30pm celebrating the theme of light, to include works by Eric Whitacre, Jonathan Dove and Edward Elgar.Â  Tickets: adult Â£10, child Â£5.Â  Call Chester Cathedral Box Office on 01244 500959 or visit www.chestercathedral.com.
CONGLETON: Clonterâs 40th anniversary kicks off with its annual opera prize concert at Clonter Opera Theatre in Swettenham Heath at 7.30pm. Tickets Â£30, Â£25, Â£20, students Â£10. Call 01260 224514 or visit www.clonteropera.com.
WIRRAL: Liverpool Mozart Orchestra, conducted by Mark Heron with soloist Yuanfan Yang (piano), BBC Young Musician 2012 Finalist, performing works by Brahms, Beethoven and Dvorak, at the Floral Pavilion in New Brighton at 7.30pm. Call 0151 666 0000 or visit www.floralpavilion.com.
Â 
SUNDAY, FEBRUARY 9
CHESTER: Stepping Out Swing Band in concert at Alexanderâs in Rufus Court, 7.15 for 7.45pm. Tickets Â£7. Call 01925 502192.
Â 
TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 11
BANGOR: Graham Eccles gives the lunchtime organ recital in Bangor Cathedral at 1.10pm. Retiring collection.
CHESTER: Lunchtime concert given by Chetham's School of Music Pianists at 12.45pm at the Wesley Church Centre, St John Street. Admission Â£3. Call 01244 379275.
Â 
WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 12
CHESTER: Chester Music Society presents Brodsky String Quartet - Daniel Rowland (violin), Ian Belton (violin), Paul Cassidy (viola), Jacqueline Thomas (cello) - perform works by Wolf, Puccini, Schubert and Respighi at St Maryâs Centre at 7.30pm. Tickets Â£13. Call 01928 381995 or visit www.chestermusicsociety.org.uk.
Â 
THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 13
CHESTER: Benjamin Chewter plays music by Widor, KodÃ¡ly, Bach, Liszt and Stanford, in his lunchtime organ recital in Chester Cathedral at 1.10pm. Admission Â£5.45, concessions Â£4.50. Accompanied children under 16 free.
CHESTER: Piano recital by Tristan Lee and Gintaute Gataveckaite at The Hammond School at Hoole Bank House at 7.30pm. Tickets Â£10, concessions Â£6. Call 01244 305350.
SHOWS
CHESTER: February 8 - Comedy Live! featuring Sully OâSullivan, at Alexanderâs, Rufus Court. Admission Â£12, members Â£10. Call 01244 340005 or visit www.alexanderslive.com.
Â 
CHESTER: February 15 - Howard Marks presents Scholar, Smuggler, Prisoner, Scribe, at The Live Rooms, Homer House, Station Road at 7pm. With trademark honesty and penetrating humour, Howard will look back at four extraordinary and action packed phases of his life. Tickets Â£17. Visit www.theliverooms.com/www.seetickets.com.
Â 
CREWE: February 7 - Abbamania - From Dancing Queen to Waterloo their record-breaking songs are timeless and continue to thrill generations. Abbamania are widely regarded as the UKâs top Abba tribute show which can be seen at the Lyceum Theatre in Heath Street at 7.30pm. Tickets Â£19.50, Â£17.50. Call 01270 368242 or visit www.crewelyceum.co.uk.
Â 
ELLESMERE PORT: February 13 - West Cheshire College drama department presents Oh What A Lovely War! at John Prescott Theatre, West Cheshire College, Ellesmere Port Campus, at 7pm. Tickets Â£5. There is also a free performance at 1pm. Call 01244 656308.
Â 
LIVERPOOL: February 5-6 - Bella: Queen of the Blackfriars Ring - The story of legendary boxing promoter Bella Burge on her journey from being the confidante and dresser of music hall queen, Marie Lloyd, to losing everything in the blitz in 1940. A show with live music, song, dance and boxing at the Unity Theatre in Hope Place at 8pm. Tickets Â£10, concessions Â£8. Call 0844 873 2888 or visit www.unitytheatreliverpool.co.uk.
Â 
MOLD: February 6 - Kill For A Seat Comedy Club presents Ben Norris and Ray Peacock, with resident compere Silky, in the Clwyd Room at Clwyd Theatr Cymru at 8pm. Tickets Â£10, concessions Â£8. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theatr-cymru.co.uk.
Â 
RUNCORN: February 4-8 - Bentley Operatic Society presents Iolanthe by Gilbert and Sullivan, at The Brindley, High Street. Ring 0151 907 8360 or visit www.thebrindley.org.uk.
Â 
RUNCORN: February 13 - Comedian Andrew OâNeill - A hilarious tour through heavy metal by the UKâs foremost metalhead stand up comedian, at The Brindley, High Street. Ring 0151 907 8360 or visit www.thebrindley.org.uk.
EXHIBITIONS
CHESTER: Until March 28 - Street Life - From washing the flags and snatched minutes of gossip to children playing out safely until dusk and the glowing lights of the corner shop spilling out on winter evenings, our streets were the background of our lives. This exhibition at Chester History and Heritage in Bridge Street takes us back to those times.
CHESTER: Until March 28 - Picking A Pocket Or Two - While Victorian Chester was a round of pleasure and power for the most affluent, for those living in abject poverty, petty theft, prostitution and drunkenness could seem to some to be the only way out of their hopelessness. Using prison photographs and contemporary local newspaper reports, this foyer display allows us a glimpse into a different world where people risked their freedom for a stolen handkerchief, a coin or a petticoat, at Chester History and Heritage in Bridge Street.
CHESTER: February 1-May 11 - Reverse Angle: Andy Hollingworth portraits 2005-2014 - Andy Hollingworthâs photographic portraits grace the posters, DVD sleeves and book jackets or our most famous and infamous comedians. This exhibition features 50 iconic and never before seen images captured in the studio during live performances and behind the scenes at television and radio recordings. It provides a rare chance to see artists like Michael McIntyre, Lee Evans, Bill Bailey, Harry Hill, Sarah Millican, Rowan Atkinson and Steve Martin in a new light, in the Grosvenor Museum Exhibition Gallery One.
CHESTER: February 8-May 5 - The Long Art and Short Life of Randolph Caldecott - The Victorian illustrator sometimes felt that he had too much work to do and not enough time to do it in, that âart is long, life isnâtâ. His words turned out to be prophetic as not only is his work still used as a standard for exceptional childrenâs book illustrations but he was only 39 when he died. This exhibition explores the joyful, vibrant and witty art of this Chester born artist who was one of the most respected illustrators of his time at the Grosvenor Museum Exhibition Gallery Two.
CHESTER: January 10-February 14 - Exhibition of work by Russell Kirk at Contemporary Art Space Chester, University of Chester, Faculty of Arts and Media, Kingsway. Call 01244 515870 or visit www.chester.ac.uk/casc.
CHESTER: Until 2015 - Motherhood - this small exhibition explores the role of motherhood between 1860 and 1960 with interpretation extending into the surrounding period rooms. Recognising that the role is not always fulfilled by the biological mother, the exhibition examines the themes of baby and child care, home making and time out. Through objects, costumes and ephemera, the exhibition considers the roles of motherhood, labour saving equipment and the implications of social developments during a century of enormous change, in the Grosvenor Museum Costume Gallery.
CHESTER: From February 5 at Chester Cathedral.Â  Tony Evans sculpture exhibition daily with free entry.Â  Tony specialises in animals in action and works mainly with copper and bronze. His portrayals of nature capture the spirit and the splendour of a whole menagerie of animals - ranging from the simplicity of a frog to the magnificence of a life-size Bengal tiger.
ELLESMERE PORT: March 5-April 29 - Exhibition of paintings by Rob Pointon at the National Waterways Museum. A wide and varied collection including some of Rob's Year of the Boat paintings together with other work. Call 0151 355 5017 for details.
ELLESMERE PORT: February 7-21 - International Monetary Failure - Money Art Exhibition - featuring artists from the UK, USA, Belgium and France at The Paperboat Gallery in Whitby Road. Call 0151 378 1794.
MOLD: February 12-March 10 - Alun School exhibition of KS3 work including work based on Tin Can Sally (mixed media birds and poems), Ai wei wei (low relief animal heads) and David Hockney (paintings and iPad work), in the Education Gallery at Clwyd Theatr Cymru. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theratr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: February 10-March 1 - Mountain, sea and landscapes from North Wales and beyond by Louise Martin, in the Community Gallery at Clwyd Theatr Cymru. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theratr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: January 20-February 8 - Poison Apples and Broken Chairs by Andrea Davies - this exhibition sets out to question the âhappily ever afterâ with a series of drawings and prints attemptingÂ  to rewrite fairy tales, moving them forward and experiencing them from the perspective of an adult, in the Community Gallery at Clwyd Theatr Cymru. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theratr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: January 18-March 1 - Reparation and Restitution -The Forgotteon Evolutionist by Fred Langford Edwards - an exhibition exploring the life, ideas and surviving collections of Alfred Russell Wallace, the physical hardships he endured during his travels and his contributions to the theories of natural selection and evolution. Edwardsâ project has been to generate artworks, publications and activities which will reinstate Wallace as a major contributor to the ideas and processes that explain how species gradually change to create new types of beings, at the Oriel Gallery at Clwyd Theatr Cymru. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theratr-cymru.co.uk.
MOLD: January 15-February 10 - Flintshire Schools Art Exhibition Rhymes and Riddles - professional artist Eleri Jones has been working with pupils from Ysgol Trelawnyd, Ysgol Esgob and Ysgol Nercwys to create artwork based on Rhymes and Riddles, in the Education Gallery at Clwyd Theatr Cymru. Call 0845 330 3565 or visit www.clwyd-theratr-cymru.co.uk.
WARRINGTON: February 3-28 - Is Cleaning Cleansing â an exhibition by Lisa Wood - Lisaâs work seeks to manifest individual or collective emotions in a tangible form, using media manipulations as a conduit for such representations. She uses many disciplines and media, such as â casting, photography, film and performance. Her exhibition can be seen at the Pyramid in Palmyra Square. Call 01925 442345 or visit www.pyramidparrhall.com.
Â 
WARRINGTON: February 6 - Comedian Ed Byrne presents Roaring Forties -Â  A self-confessed âmiserable old gitâ since the age of 23, Ed Byrne is now in his forties. While for others this might result in a crisis that prompts the purchase of a sportscar, Ed embraces middle age with open arms, at the Parr Hall in Palmyra Square at 8pm. Tickets Â£22.50. Call 01925 442345 or visit www.pyramidparrhall.com.
Â 
WIRRAL: February 9 - Bananas in Pyjamas Live at the Floral Pavilion, New Brighton, at 1pm. Itâs partytime in Cuddlestown Park but the guest of honourâs gone missing! Itâs a Banana emergency! Help the Bananas and their friends find the guest of honour whilst singing some of your favourite kids tunes and laughing along to lots and lots of jokes! Join B1, B2, Amy, Lulu and Morgan in this brand new show that will have you dancing in the aisles! Call 0151 632 5170 for details.
Â 
WIRRAL: February 9 - Claire Knight (Irby Dance Studio) presents A Musical Experience - Take 2, at the Gladstone Theatre at 2.30pm. Tickets Â£10, concessions Â£8. Call 0151 608 6118 or visit www.gladstonetheatre.org.uk.
Â

Fleetwood Town continue their remarkable rise with a victory over Newport

Ac maeâr agweddau diobaith yn llawer uwch ymhlith pobol ifanc syân methu Ã¢ chael o leiaf bump TGAU rhwng A* ac C.
Mae un o bob tri oâr rheinyân disgwyl gorffen ar fudd-daliadau ac un o bob pump yn dweud eu bod wedi rhoiâr gorau i bob uchelgais.
ganlyniad, fe alwodd Ymddiriedolaeth y Tywysog â noddwyr y gwaith ymchwil â fod angen rhagor o gefnogaeth i bobol ifanc gyda gyrfa a swyddi.
Problemau cartref yn cael effaith
Yn Ã´l yr Ymddiriedolaeth, mae amgylchiadau cartref yn gallu gwneud llawer o wahaniaeth hefyd.
Roedd canran llawer uwch o bobol ifanc heb 5 TGAU da yn dweud fod âproblemau teuluolâ yn amharu ar eu gwaith â 29% oâi gymharu Ã¢ 12% o bobol ifanc yn gyffredinol.
blith yr un garfan, dim ond 44% oedd Ã¢ defnydd o gyfrifiadur gartreâ oâi gymharu Ã¢ 70% yn gyffredinol.
Gobeithion yn cael eu chwalu
âMae gobeithion miloedd o bobol ifanc yn cael eu chwalu gan ganlyniadau arholiadau bob blwyddyn,â meddai Martina Milburn, Prif Weithredwr yr Ymddiriedolaeth.
âMae llawer oâr bobol ifanc yma wedi wynebu problemau gartref neu fwlio yn yr ysgol, felly dyw eu canlyniadau mewn arholiadau ddim yn adlewyrchu eu gwir botensial.â

Y cefndir
Roedd yr arolwg wedi cael ei gynnal ar ran yr Ymddiriedolaeth gan y corff polau piniwn YouGov.
Roedden nhw wedi holi 2342 o bobol ifanc rhwng 16 a 25.
Roedd llawer oâr rheinyân aros am ganlyniadau arholiadau a chanran uchel yn dweud bod hynnyân effeithio ar eu hiechyd.

Tony Benn: My political career
14 March 2014 Last updated at 09:17 GMT
Former Cabinet minister and veteran left-wing campaigner Tony Benn has died at home, his family has said.
A few weeks before his death, he spoke to the Today programme's James Naughtie about his political career.
First broadcast on BBC Radio 4's Today programme on Friday 14 March.

Cookie Information
This site uses cookies to store information on your device to help us improve the experience of our visitors.
To find out more about the cookies this site uses, please see the links on the left. You can also read our Terms and Conditions for more detailed information.
You can change your mind at any point and update your cookies preferences by clicking on the 'cookies' tab at the top of the page. Note: the selection below applies to this website only.
Compliance Cookie
The compliance cookie remembers the choice that is made here. No personal information is collected about you or about your computer.
Analytics Cookies
We use Google Analytics, a popular web analytics service provided by Google, Inc. Google Analytics uses cookies to help us to analyse how users use the site. It counts the number of visitors and tells us things about their behavior overall â such as the typical length of stay on the site or the average number of pages a user views.
No personal information is collected about you or about your computer. Please read our Terms and Conditions for more information about how we use Google Analytics cookies.
Functional/Session Cookies
This site does not use functional cookies. Functional cookies are used for activities such as logging in to a site and completing online forms. They do not contain any personal information and for the most part are automatically deleted when you close your browser.

Issue - meetings
Grand Parade and Undercroft
Details
History
Decisions
Meetings
Â 
Â 
Meeting:
10/10/2012 - Cabinet (Item 82)
82 Grand Parade and Undercroft PDF 66 KB
The Grand Parade
& Undercroft project presents a
unique development opportunity for the World Heritage City of
Bath.Â  It represents an opportunity to
bring redundant and inefficient space back into use for community
and commercial benefit, whilst also creating a new fully accessible
destination point for business and tourism.
:
Additional documents:
E2451zAppendix1, item 82
PDF 971 KB
Minutes:
Councillor Brian Webber said that he
wished the project well and was delighted that plans were being
made to bring the Undercroft back into public use.
Councillor Peter Anketell-Jones
agreed, but felt that the plan would not mitigate the costs of the
Guildhall, as was apparently anticipated.Â  The project lacked a clear objective, and not
enough detail had been given to enable Cabinet to make an informed
decision.
Councillor David Bellotti in
proposing the item, said that a successful meeting had been held
with the market traders, who were excited about the new
opportunities it would provide.Â  He
explained that the plans included a mix of retail, leisure and food
outlets which would be a valuable use of an area which was
currently wasted space.Â  The project
would not be about the Council spending large sums of money as it
was seeking partners to achieve the project.Â  He felt that the timetable was ambitious but
achievable.Â  He explained that he would
be moving slightly different proposals from those recommended in
the officer report and a further report would only be brought to
Cabinet if a decision was required.
Councillor Cherry Beath seconded the
proposal and said that the Cabinet was keen to develop the
underused areas of Bath.Â  She was
confident that good progress would be made towards bringing the
colonnades back into public use.
On a motion from Councillor David
Bellotti, seconded by Councillor Cherry Beath, it was
RESOLVED
(unanimously)
(1) To AGREE that a detailed
consultation exercise should be undertaken with key stakeholders
and the general public;
(2) To AGREE that a development brief
should be produced, taking into account the feedback from the
consultation exercise, to enable a development partner to be
procured;
(3) To ASK the Chief Property Officer
to produce a full viability appraisal and options report on the
opportunities under consideration; and
(4) To AGREE that on completion of
the above recommendations, if required, a further report will be
submitted to Cabinet for approval.
:

Tagiau: Brian Flynn, PÃªl-droed rhyngwladol
Mae deuddydd cyn i Gymru herio Bwlgaria mewn gÃªm dyngedfennol i obeithion ein hymgyrch rhagbrofol Ewro 2012. Owain Schiavone syân awgrymu y bydd rheolwr dros droâr tÃ®m rhyngwladol, Brian Flynn yn teimlo rhwystredigaeth wrth baratoi ei garfanâ¦
Cwta fis yn ei swydd fel rheolwr dros dro Cymru, a cyn ei gÃªm gyntaf wrth y llyw, ac mae Brian Flynn yn gwybod yn union am y rhwystredigaeth yr oedd John Toshack yn ei deimlo yn ystod ei chwe blynedd yntauân rheoliâr tÃ®m rhyngwladol.
Roedd Flynn yn gwybod cyn derbyn y swydd y byddai dau o sÃªr mwyaf disglair Cymru, Aaron Ramsey a Jack Collison, yn eisiau ar gyfer y gemau yn erbyn Bwlgaria aâr Swistir syân cael eu chwarae dros yr wythnos nesaf.
Penbleth Bellamy
Â 
Daeth yr ergyd fawr gyntaf iâw gynlluniau felly pan ddaeth iâr amlwg na fyddaiâr capten, Craig Bellamy, yn ffit i fod yn ei garfan. Digon teg o ystyried ar y pryd nad oedd Bellamy wedi chwaraeâr un gÃªm i Gaerdydd ers iddo frifo ei ben-glin yn y gÃªm yn erbyn Montenegro. Beth syân peri penbleth ydyâr ffaith i Bellamy chwarae gÃªm lawn iâw glwb yn erbyn Barnsley ddydd Sadwrn, gan edrych mor ffit ag erioed wrth arwain ei dÃ®m i fuddugoliaeth.
Mae adroddiadauân awgrymu fod Flynn a Dave Jones wedi dod i ddealltwriaeth ynglÅ·n Ã¢ Bellamy, a bod cytundeb rhyngddynt nad yw ei ben-glin yn ddigon cryf i chwarae dwy gÃªm mewn wythnos ar hyn o bryd. Wedi dweud hynny, maeân rhyfedd iawn na fydd capten Cymru yn cymryd unrhyw ran yn yr un oâr ddwy gÃªm syân gwbl dyngedfennol iâr ymgyrch ragbrofolâ¦ac efallai cyfle olaf Bellamy i chwarae mewn rowndiau terfynol iâw wlad. Efallai bod mwy iddi nad ydan niân gwybod amdano, ond rhaid dweud bod parodrwydd Flynn i roi mewn i Jones yn awgrymu gwendid yn y rheolwr newydd.
Er gwaethaf absenoldeb Bellamy, roedd golwg digon soled iâr garfan a gafodd ei enwi gan Flynn ddydd Gwener diwethaf. Roedd rhai oâr enwau ifanc newydd yn y garfan yn awgrymu bod Flynn yn sicr aâi olygon ar ddyfodol tymor hir yn y swydd, traâi bod hefyd yn braf gweld enwauâr ddau Danny, Gabbidon a Collins nÃ´l yn y dewis o amddiffynwyr.
Sbaner yn y wyrcs
Dechreuodd pethau fynd o chwith i Flynn ddydd Llun, gydaâr newyddion fod Rob Earnshaw wedi tynnu nÃ´l oâr garfan gydag anaf.
Cafodd Flynn ergyd arall iâw gynlluniau yn hwyrach y diwrnod hwnnw wrth i Danny Gabbidon benderfynu ei bod yn bryd ymddeol o bÃªl-droed rhyngwladol. Dymaâr math o sefyllfa a gododd droeon yn ystod teyrnasiad John Toshack wrth gwrs. Mae Gabbidon wedi cael amser erchyll gydag anafiadau dros y ddwy flynedd ddiwethaf, ac mae rhywun yn deall ei benderfyniad er mwyn ceisio diogelu ei ddyfodol ar lefel clwb. Yr hyn dwiân methu aâi ddeall ydy pam cyhoeddiâr newyddion ddyddiau ar Ã´l iddo gael ei enwi yng ngharfan Cymru? Roedd Gabbidon bownd o fod yn gwybod ei fod yn mynd i gael ei enwi yn y garfan felly pam ddim rhoi gwybod i Flynn cyn iddo wneud y cyhoeddiad yn hytrach na rhoi ergyd iâw gynlluniau fel hyn? Does dim amheuaeth fod Gabbidon wedi bod yn was ffyddlon iâw wlad dros y blynyddoedd felly maeâr ffordd y mae wedi ymdrin Ã¢ hyn yn siomedig.
Daeth yr ergyd ddiweddaraf i Flynn ddoe gydaâr newyddion bod Brian Stock o Doncaster a Neal Eardley o Blackpool yn tynnu nÃ´l gydag anafiadau. Yn wahanol i Gabbidon, maeân annhebygol y byddaiâr un oâr rhain wedi dechrauâr gÃªm yn erbyn Bwlgaria. Er hynny, petai chwaraewyr yn codi anafiadau neu waharddiad oâr gÃªm honno, yna bydden nhw wedi bod yn ddefnyddiol ar gyfer yr ail gÃªm allan yn y Swistir. Mae hynnyân arbennig o wir yn achos Eardley sydd wedi bod yn chwaraeân rheolaidd i Blackpool yn yr Uwch Gynghrair eleni.
Ychwanegu enwau defnyddiol
Er y gellid dadlau mae chwaraewyr ymylol ydy tri oâr rhain, mae colli pum chwaraewr yn mynd i wanhau carfan ac mae gweld chwaraewyr yn tynnu nÃ´l rhoiâr neges anghywir.
Â 
Mae Flynn wedi ychwanegu Darcy Blake, Neil Taylor, Andrew Crofts a Ryan Doble iâr garfan bellach. Mae Crofts wedi sgorio tair gÃ´l mewn 10 gÃªm Bencampwriaeth i Norwich eleni gan helpu ei dÃ®m i gyrraedd y trydydd safle yn y gynghrair, felly maeân syndod nad oedd yn y garfan beth bynnag. Mae Blake hefyd wedi bod yn chwaraeân rheolaidd i Gaerdydd ac mae ei allu i chwarae mewn nifer o safleoedd yn golygu ei fod yn foi defnyddiol iâw gael yn y garfan.Â 
Mae enw Ryan Doble yn un diddorol hefyd. Dim ond 19 oed ydy Doble, a tydi o ddim wedi chwarae i dÃ®m cyntaf Southampton eto. Er hynny, fe chwaraeodd ei gÃªm gyntaf i dÃ®m dan-21 Cymru yn erbyn Hwngari fis diwethaf ac maeân amlwg fod gan Flynn feddwl mawr ohono.Â 
Gan gymryd na fydd yna fwy o chwaraewyr yn tynnu nÃ´l oâr garfan, mae gan Flynn ddigon o chwaraewyr i ddewis tÃ®m a all guro Bwlgaria nos Wener. Gan ddibynnu ar y system y bydd Flynn yn ei mabwysiadu, dwiân disgwyl iâr tÃ®m edrych rhywbeth fel hyn:
1)Â Â Â Â Â  Wayne Hennessey

Un chwaraewr a allai orfodi ei ffordd mewn iâr XI cyntaf ydy Andy King o Leicester, ac os fydd Flynn yn dewis chwarae gyda phump yng nghanol cae maeân bosib y bydd yn cael ei ddewis cyn Simon Church.
Â 
Maeâr amddiffyn, gydag ychwanegiad Danny Collins syân awyddus i greu argraff, yn edrych yn ddigon soled. Maeâr canol cae yn cynnwys 4 chwaraewr syân chwarae ar y lefel uchaf yn Lloegr aâr Alban hefyd, ond byddai gallu ychwanegu Ramsey a Collison yn gwneud cymaint o wahaniaeth. Y broblem fwyaf i Flynn fydd sgorio goliau ac unwaith eto dwiân gweld y dasg yn disgyn i Steve Morison o Milwall sydd wedi sgorio 4 gÃ´l mewn 10 gÃªm iâw glwb hyd yn hyn eleni. Bydd angen iddo drosglwyddoâr hwyl yna i lefel rhyngwladol os oes gobaith i Gymru gipio 4 pwynt oâr ddwy gÃªm yma.
Ta ta Tosh!
Cyhoeddwyd Medi 8, 2010 gan Cyfranwyr Gwadd. 1 Sylw.
Tagiau: John Toshack, PÃªl-droed, PÃªl-droed rhyngwladol

âY peth gorau am golli yn Montenegro yw ymadawiad hir-ddisgwyliedig yr hyfforddwr.â
Fe aeth bron i 500 o gefnogwyr Cymru draw i Fontenegro yn llawn gobaith, gyda llawer yn ffyddiog fod y chwaraewyr ifanc sydd wedi chwarae i Gymru dros y blynyddoedd diwethaf yn barod i gystadlu gyda goreuon y grÅµp a cheisio am le yn Ewro 2012.

More from Robert
Is Tesco on the turn?
Â 
More from Robert
No fall in Barclays bonuses
Who isnât probing banksâ alleged currency rigging?
Is UK's housing-finance system broken?
Lloyds: 'Normal' again
Depending on how you measure it, Justin King has probably avoided the minor embarrassment of winning two accolades from his boss rivals (the chief executive they admire most) and simultaneously being obliged to announce the end of growth.
In the third quarter of its year, Sainsbury's underlying, or like-for-like, sales grew a tiny bit, 0.2%, excluding fuel, and were flat as a pancake including fuel. This compares with rises of 2.1% and 2% respectively in the strong second quarter of the year.
Is that a bump in the road after an extraordinary 35 quarters of unbroken growth? Yes, but not one such that King is likely to feel desperately uncomfortable.
More interesting is the piece of the jigsaw Sainsbury's provides to explain what happened to retailers and to household consumption in the Christmas period.
As I said on Monday, October and much of November were difficult months for the high street. But the Christmas period itself was strong, with King saying the seven days prior to 25 December were the busiest ever for the business.
The other important trends for all retailers were these:
Sales of more expensive items - cars, televisions, tablets and so on - were strong. At Sainsbury's, there was a 25% jump in tableware and 30% in "gifting".
2013 was the year in which online sales wagged the entire retailing dog, in a revolution that is permanent. The best performing store chains, Next, John Lewis and House of Fraser, are those with huge and efficient online presences. And at Sainsbury's, online grocery sales rose more than 10%.
The confidence of shoppers that online purchases will arrive in a timely way is shown by 22 December being Sainsbury's biggest-ever day for internet sales. In previous years, digital sales had tapered off so close to Christmas.
So what about Tesco, Sainsbury's much bigger rival, which reports tomorrow?
My hunch is that this Christmas will have been good for Tesco, in the sense of how its owners see the course and strategy set by the chief executive Philip Clarke.
This is not to say that the headline numbers will look great. There is bound to have been a fall in like-for-like, or underlying, sales, and so the simple direct comparison with Sainsbury's will not flatter Tesco.
But that disguises Tesco's strengths - especially in online - which Clarke is reinforcing.
âStart Quote
Over the course of a year, the share of digital in Tesco's sales is said to have jumped several percentage pointsâ
End Quote
Clarke has made a big and expensive bet that the future will be digital, and not about huge out-of-town stores.
The fruits of that are not yet conspicuous, in that there is still a big drag on sales from the way Clarke has permanently rebalanced sales away from less intrinsically profitable general merchandise towards food in the big stores and from the declining popularity of vast superstores.
But internet sales are growing at a remarkable rate - analysts believe digital, from a much bigger starting point than at Sainsbury's, has grown at a double-digit rate and rather faster than Sainsbury's.
And over the course of a year, the share of digital in Tesco's sales is said to have jumped several percentage points from under 5% of sales. For a business of Tesco's size - with its 10% share of the entire retail market - that is quite something.
Clarke has been reinforcing Tesco's "multi-channel" approach with the almost 500,000 own-brand Hudl tablets it sold in just the past few months. He is thought to have plans to follow up with another tablet and a smart phone.
As a result of digital, especially the so-called click-and-collect, approach to sales, Tesco has unrivalled access to UK consumers. For example, the citizens of Stornoway and the Hebrides will shortly be able to order online and collect their groceries from a depot by the ferry port.
All of which is not to say that Tesco will suddenly find itself increasing its profits as it did in the Leahy and Maclaurin years. Those days are gone, probably forever - because Tesco's market share is now so enormous, and is at the limit of what consumers are likely to tolerate.
But after their initial doubts, Tesco's owners may start to feel more confident that Clarke is keeping the giant baby in the bathwater, rather than - as they feared - seeing it disappear down the plughole.
Â

I think i'll stick with Waitrose, the shooping experience on or off line is pleasant, the product quality is good, the prices competitive. The partners (staff) are both professional and helpful.
Report this comment (Comment number 157)
Link to this (Comment number 157)
rate this
+4
rate this
+4
Comment number 156.
Just_Me
8th January 2014 - 16:51 I hope that Tesco and Sainsbury's are both successful given that they are huge employers of many people and that we chose to shop there, no one forced us to stop going to smaller shops. We wanted cheap and convenient, we can't complain.

Fife Today provides news, events and sport features from the Kirkcaldy area. For the best up to date information relating to Kirkcaldy and the surrounding areas visit us at Fife Today regularly or bookmark this page.
For you to enjoy all the features of this website Fife Today requires permission to use cookies.
Allow Cookies
Find Out More â¼
What is a Cookie?
What is a Flash Cookie?
Can I opt out of receiving Cookies?
About our Cookies
Cookies are small data files which are sent to your browser (Internet Explorer, Firefox, Chrome etc) from a website you visit. They are stored on your electronic device.
This is a type of cookie which is collected by Adobe Flash media player (it is also called a Local Shared Object) - a piece of software you may already have on your electronic device to help you watch online videos and listen to podcasts.
Yes there are a number of options available, you can set your browser either to reject all cookies, to allow only "trusted" sites to set them, or to only accept them from the site you are currently on.
However, please note - if you block/delete all cookies, some features of our websites, such as remembering your login details, or the site branding for your local newspaper may not function as a result.
The types of cookies we, our ad network and technology partners use are listed below:
Revenue Science âº
A tool used by some of our advertisers to target adverts to you based on pages you have visited in the past. To opt out of this type of targeting you can visit the 'Your Online Choices' website by clicking here.
Google Ads âº
Our sites contain advertising from Google; these use cookies to ensure you get adverts relevant to you. You can tailor the type of ads you receive by visiting here or to opt out of this type of targeting you can visit the 'Your Online Choices' website by clicking here.
Webtrends / Google Analytics âº
This is used to help us identify unique visitors to our websites. This data is anonymous and we cannot use this to uniquely identify individuals and their usage of the sites.
Dart for Publishers âº
This comes from our ad serving technology and is used to track how many times you have seen a particular ad on our sites, so that you don't just see one advert but an even spread. This information is not used by us for any other type of audience recording or monitoring.
ComScore âº
ComScore monitor and externally verify our site traffic data for use within the advertising industry. Any data collected is anonymous statistical data and cannot be traced back to an individual.
Local Targeting âº
Our Classified websites (Photos, Motors, Jobs and Property Today) use cookies to ensure you get the correct local newspaper branding and content when you visit them. These cookies store no personally identifiable information.
Grapeshot âº
We use Grapeshot as a contextual targeting technology, allowing us to create custom groups of stories outside out of our usual site navigation. Grapeshot stores the categories of story you have been exposed to. Their privacy policy and opt out option can be accessed here.
Subscriptions Online âº
Our partner for Newspaper subscriptions online stores data from the forms you complete in these to increase the usability of the site and enhance user experience.
Add This âº
Add This provides the social networking widget found in many of our pages. This widget gives you the tools to bookmark our websites, blog, share, tweet and email our content to a friend.
3rd Party Cookies âº
We use Advertising agencies to provide us with some of the advertising on our websites. These include (but are not limited to) Specific Media, The Rubicon Project, AdJug, AdConion, Context Web. Please click on the provider name to visit their opt-out page.
